habitat_description: In Arizona Upland Desertscrub, this species is found through canyon bottoms into bajadas, and in proximity to springs or tinajas (Brennan and Holycross 2009). It also occurs on the higher elevation mountains in its restricted habitat of the Arizona Upland subdivision of the Sonoran desert. Its elevational range begins at 396 to 1402m. The red-backed whiptail is associated with palo verde, mixed cacti, subtropical shrubs, yuccas, agaves, prickly pears, and grasses (Jones and Lovich 2009). Its distribution expands across northwestern Mexico and southwestern United States; southern Arizona, southwestern New Mexico, Sonora, and Sinaloa (Stebbins 2003). Degenhardt et al. (1996) reported the occurrence of this species in Guadalupe Canyon, Hidalgo County, New Mexico, at 1321 to 1387 meters.
